description.narrative:
Den föreslagna insatsen har till syfte att inrätta ett Nationellt System för hantering av hälsoinformation och data så kallad "Health Management Information System” (HMIS) i Somalia. Det finns inget sådant initiativ för närvarande i Somalia. Etablering av ett effektivt HMIS är inkluderat i WHO:s sex grundläggande byggstenar för hälso- och sjukvårdssystem. Nuvarande fragmentering och brist på data och information gör det svårt om inte omöjligt för Somaliska hälsovårdsaktörer att kostnadseffektivt planera, hantera och leverera kvalitetshälsovård över hela landet. Insatsen skall implementeras av SPIDER (Swedish Program for ICT in Developing Regions). SPIDER grundades 2004 på Sidas initiativ och är idag ett oberoende centrum för expertis inom ICT för utveckling vid Stockholms Universitet. Sida har sedan etableringen av SPIDER fortsatt att tillhandahålla ett flerårigt icke-öronmärkt/kärnstöd till SPIDER i tillägg till specifika projekt stöd. SPIDER fungerar som den svenska operativa motparten och rådgivaren för ett antal Sida ICT för utveckling (ICT4D) projekt i Sida prioriterade länder. SPIDER mobiliserar ett nätverk av svenska och internationella experter på informations- och kommunikationsteknik för utveckling för att hjälpa utvecklingsländer använda ICT som ett verktyg för att effektivt och strategiskt driva utvecklings- och fattigdomsminskningsmål - i detta fall, hälsa.
För denna insats, föreslår SPIDER en initial 12-månaders start-fas under vilken SPIDER kommer att genomföra granskning av nuvarande data och informationssituationen och kapaciteten i Somalia, analys av regionala behov, inklusive bedömning av hälsosystemet i de två utvalda regionerna (Galmudug och Puntland ), rekrytering och utstationering av projektpersonal och kartläggning av relevanta aktörer. De två utvalda regionerna bestämdes av SPIDER i samråd med det federala hälsoministeriet i Somalia. De två utvalda regionerna återspeglar det nuvarande hälsovårdssystemet i Somalia. Galmudug-regionen representerar ett av de svagaste hälsosystemen med begränsad kapacitet och räckvidd. Galumudug-regionen kontrolleras också delvis av Al-Shabaab som gör det svårt att få tillgång till kritisk mödra-och barnhälsovård. Puntland regionen å andra sidan har ett av de mest utvecklade hälsosystemen inom Somalias federala regering. Regionen är ganska stabil och hälsoministeriet har erfarenhet jämfört med Galmudug. SPIDER föreslår vidare att skapa ett centralt nav för datalagring och hantering i Mogadishu.
Sammanfattningsvis syftar projektet till att utforma, upprätta och leverera ett HMIS som är lämpligt för Somalias infrastruktur och folkhälsobehov. Utvecklingen av HMIS är en viktig fråga för den federala regeringen och prioriteringen är inkluderad i den nationella hälsostrategin.

SPIDER was founded as a center for expertise concerning ICT for development at Sida's initiative and was initially housed by the Royal Institute of Technology and later by Stockholm University, which is Sida's agreement partner. Sida has since continued to provide a multi-year non-earmarked support to SPIDER. SPIDER acts as the Swedish operational counterpart and advisor for a number of Sida’s ICT for development (ICT4D) projects in countries prioritized by Sida. SPIDER mobilizes a network of Swedish and international experts in the area of information and communications technology (ICT) for development to help developing countries use ICT as a tool to efficiently and strategically drive development and poverty reduction goals - in this case, in the area of health. The proposed initiative aims to establish a National Health Management Information System (HMIS) in Somalia. There is no such initiative currently in the country. Establishing an effective HMIS is included in WHO's six basic building blocks for health systems. Current fragmentation and lack of data and information make it difficult, if not impossible, for Somali healthcare providers to plan, manage and deliver quality healthcare across the country in a cost-effective manner.
SPIDER proposes an initial 12-month start-up phase during which SPIDER will conduct a review of the current data and information situation and capacity in Somalia, analysis of regional needs, including an assessment of the health system in the two selected regions (Galmudug and Puntland), recruitment and posting of project staff and mapping of relevant stakeholder. The two selected regions were determined by SPIDER in consultation with the Federal Ministry of Health in Somalia. The two selected regions reflect the current healthcare system in Somalia. The Galmudug region represents one of the weakest health systems with limited capacity and reach. The Galumudug region is also partially controlled by Al-Shabaab, which makes it difficult to access critical maternal and child health care. The Puntland region, on the other hand, has one of the most developed health systems in Somalia's federal government. The region is quite stable, and the Ministry of Health has sufficient capacity and experience compared to Galmudug. SPIDER also proposes to create a central hub for data storage and management in Mogadishu. Lessons learned from the first introductory phase will guide decisions to scale up the initiative to other regions. In summary, the project aims to design, establish and deliver a health information management system for that is suitable for Somalia's infrastructure and public health needs. The development of HMIS is an important issue for the federal government and is included among seen health care priorities.

The main objective of the SPIDER initiative - Health Alliance for Digital Development and Action (HADDA) is to design and establish and deliver a National Health Management Information System (HMIS) appropriate for Somalias infrastructure and public health needs in close collaboration with the Federal Government Authorities in Somalia. The total budget for the initiative is 40 million SEK over the periods of 2019-2022. The existence of an effective and efficient national HMIS has by WHO been identified as one of six core building blocks for health systems. SPIDER will utilize digital development tools for the effective planning, management and strengthening of the health system in order to increase both the capacity and quality of health service delivery especially to hard-to-reach communities. These digital tools are expected to enhance the capacity of health care workers and policy makers to plan, manage and provide quality, accessible and equitable health care to people. The program further aims to focus on digitalization of the health system with regards to both data storage and sharing. The program is expected to integrate capacity building and data management components to foster the ongoing digitalization of HMIS. Galmudug and Puntland has been selected as pilot regions. The two selected regions reflect the full spectrum of the current health care system in Somalia. Galmudug region represents one of the weakest health systems, with limited capacity and reach. Galumudug region is also partially controlled by Al-Shabaab, which makes access to critical maternal and child health care services difficult. Puntland region on the other hand has one of the most developed health systems within the Federal Government of Somalia. The region is fairly stable, and the ministry of health has sufficient capacity and experience compared to Galmudug. SPIDER further proposes to create a central hub in Mogadishu for data storage and management.

description.narrative: Health Alliance for Digital Development and Action (HADDA) Programme (2019 2023) is the name of the SPIDER contribution. Since 2020 was an inception year the results achieved are more process-type of outcomes, and include: - Agreement between SPIDER and Federal Ministry of Health - A non-financial Memorandum of Understanding was approved and signed June 2019 between collaborating partners Spider and Federal Ministry of Health. - Spider arranged a stakeholder inception meeting in February 2020, with the objective to bring together different stakeholders and actors within the Somali health system to discuss how the participants can work together to further strengthen Somalias health-care system. Besides Sida a wide number of key stakeholders were present; The Somali government represented by the office of the prime minister, ministries of health in Puntland and Galmudug, federal ministry of labour. Other key actors within the Somali health sector present at the meeting were Public Health Agency of Sweden, Unicef, UNFPA, WHO, Save the children. During the meeting the programme was presented. In addition, the representatives of the Ministries of Health in Puntland and Galmudug, the two federal states in which the programme will be implemented, highlighted current health-care situation in Somalia, the efforts of the ministries, and the continuous challenges, in particular on the Health Management Information System. - Two local Somali partner organisations, SIDRA and KasmoDev, were recruited in July to the project after vetting by SPIDER (including PwC audit of KasmoDev) and following approval by Sida. A Project Coordinator for the SPIDER project coordinator was recruited through KasmoDev. The project coordinator is based in Somalia, and is SPIDERs representative in the region, with the responsibility to coordinate the local activities in consultation with the program manager, results follow up, evaluation of local partnerships within the program and reporting to SPIDER. - HADDA Initiation meeting - SPIDER organised a joint virtual HADDA initiation meeting with MoH officials from Federal Government of Somalia (FGS), Federal Member States (FMS) - Galmudug and Puntland present. SIDRA and KasmoDev were also present and acknowledged by the ministries as partner organisations. Confirming that HADDA aligns with the Somali National Health Agenda and in particular the priorities of the Health Management Information System, all parties agreed on the presented overview of HADDA workplan for 2020 (see overview HADDA workplan), including needs assessment and technical audit of selected health facilities, stakeholder consultation meetings to review the audit reports, discuss and develop HMIS Framework and Implementation work plan. During the HADDA initiation meeting a Technical Coordination Committee (TCC) was established that will oversee and coordinate to ensure the HADDA project aligns with the national strategic priorities as well as other health information system projects. - A formal collaboration between SPIDER and WHO was initiated and is now in the process of being formalised with a non-financial MoU. - Needs assessment and Technical review toolkit was developed by the SIDRA Research team and the technical team at KasmoDev have both independently developed comprehensive research tools and HMIS /ICT assessment toolkits respectively. The toolkits have been shared with the ministries of health for approval. WHO technical team have also reviewed and shared their feedback and input on the HMIS/ICT toolkit which has been incorporated in the final version.- Throughout 2020 SPIDER has had ongoing discussions and meetings with the Public Health Agency (PHA) Sweden on possible collaboration on strengthening of public health in Somalia through our joint efforts. Through PHA Sweden, SPIDER has had initial meeting with National Health Institute (NIH) Somalia and how a unified HMIS could benefit NIH Somalia.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
